content:
Could the UK actually get colder with global warming?

Of all the possible climate futures, there's a scenario where the United Kingdom and north-west Europe buck the trend of global warming and instead face plunging temperatures and freezing winters.

It's not the most likely outcome, but a number of scientists fear that the chance of it happening is growing, and that the consequences would be so great that it deserves proper consideration.

They are concerned that the ocean currents that bring warm water from the tropics to the North Atlantic could weaken - or even collapse - in response to climate change.

https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cn938ze4yyeo

#climate #ClimateChange #GlobalWarming #AMOC #GulfStream

content: NWS High Resolution modeling, particularly their HRRR model verified quite well, if you look what I posted a few days ago. Heavy snow in the high terrain behind town üëç. Thankfully Beartooth Highway was plowed to the 2300m closure. -19C when we left our place in town 1700m. By 2200m temp. warmed to 0C, then 4C at the winter closure. Strong W chinook winds. For some reason DOT plowed 1km in from it. Only could ski a bit, 40-70cm thick wet powder to break thru. #climatechange #gye #skiing #dogs

media_attachments.description: gave up skiing on the side of the plowed area here, getting gale force

I would say this qualifies as weather/climate whiplash here this portion of the GYE. Very warm/dry Oct-early Jan. Now much colder, quickly and snowier. The atmospheric river pattern we had last two days was a strong producer. Which we need, but just do not want too much, real quickly. https://www.nature.com/articles/s43017-024-00624-z
skied for an hour 'round the hood this afternoon. cold -18C with a stiff N breeze. easily 30cm or more new last two days.

media_attachments.description: The image shows a screenshot of a Twitter post by Michael E. Mann, with a brief excerpt from a summary. The summary describes the collapse of civilizations, focusing on the dynamics of the interaction between population and natural resources, and the division of society into Elites and Commoners. Below this, is a second post with text mentioning a 10-year-old paper by a colleague, Eugenia Kalnay, and the effects of environmental degradation and wealth disparity on societal stability. The post also includes a link to a website.

A tweet by Michael E. Mann contains an image with a graph. The graph has a horizontal axis labeled "Time (Year)" and the vertical axis is labeled "1 Xm". The graph has five lines: a green line representing Nature, a gray line representing Wealth, a blue line representing Commoners, and a red line representing Elites. The graph shows the carrying capacity of the society, represented in orange. The tweet also displays the text ‚ÄúHuman and nature dynamics (HANDY): Modeling inequality and use of resources in the collapse or sustainability of societies‚Äù.

content:
#ClimateChange #EU

"Goodbye Gouda and farewell French mustard: Signature foods on the brink of climate extinction.

Dijon mustard was recently so damaged by climate change, French retailers limited customers to a single jar each.

It‚Äôs no secret that extreme weather conditions, driven by human-created climate change, are endangering the global food supply system.

Droughts, heatwaves, wildfires and floods combine to wreak havoc on staple crops such as wheat and rice, as well as seafood, coffee and chocolate. But as well as the obvious impacts on the global food chain - famines, food shortages and drastic price increases ‚Äì we may soon see the end of countries‚Äô traditional gastronomic cultures."

https://www.euronews.com/green/2025/02/13/goodbye-gouda-and-farewell-french-mustard-signature-foods-on-the-brink-of-climate-extincti

content:
More autumn tropical cyclone genesis in the South China Sea during El Ni√±o to La Ni√±a transition

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41612-025-00947-8

#China #ClimateChange #GlobalWarming #IrreversibleOverheating #GlobalBurning #ClimateDestruction #ClimateSuicide #MassExtinction #pollution #ecology #environment #climate

card.title: More autumn tropical cyclone genesis in the South China Sea during El Ni√±o to La Ni√±a transition - npj Climate and Atmospheric Science
card.description: Previous studies focused on the spatial diversity of ENSO‚Äôs influence on tropical cyclones (TCs) in the western North Pacific (WNP), with less emphasis on temporal evolution. This study examines the variability of TC genesis in the WNP during boreal autumn (September-November) across three types of La Ni√±a transitions: cyclic, multi-year, and episodic. The findings highlight significant differences, particularly in the South China Sea‚Äôs (SCS) role within the WNP region. During a cyclic La Ni√±a, the SCS TC frequency is approximately 2.6 times greater than those of the other two types due to higher local humidity from increased water vapor transport from the Indian Ocean and convergence in the SCS, driven by an anomalous cyclone in the SCS and Maritime Continent. Observations and model simulations revealed that a warmer sea surface temperature in the Philippine Sea, a delayed effect of the preceding El Ni√±o, triggered this cyclonic circulation and moisture influx.

content:
Planted extra #snowdrop bulbs in the green at the weekend. Did not take long at all‚Äîjust as well, there was an icy wind, which made being outside unpleasant‚Äîand gave me a chance to use my new #Hori Hori knife for the first time.
Despite its name, it is not a knife but a #Japanese #trowel. Manufacturer suggests to use it as an all-round weeder, bulb-planter and general subterranean rummager.
They also call the Hori Hori a weed digging, plant dividing, seed drilling, bulb planting, pot scraping, stone prising, ivy removing, subterranean rummaging, life saving, rooting tooting all round game-changer.
Hm ‚Ä¶ After using it once I think that they may have a point.
‚Ä£ Upright. Click to see all.

content:
Sharing this soothing weekend read from Ken Coulson, the author of ‚ÄúThe Arsonist.‚Äù

The Arsonist is a corporate thriller and modern day David and Goliath Story about the collision of Wall Street and the Climate Crisis.

:earth: :ExtinctionRebellion:

Now is a time to think about cultivation, what will we plant in our gardens this year? How will we prepare? When do we start?

A garden is a commitment, just as a seed is hope. It requires fortitude, persistence, adaptation, resilience, and, of course, patience. Some would say luck, too, is a key ingredient. Maybe most of all, our gardens require love.

Read it here: https://theculturaleaston.com/2025/02/22/the-garden/
